docs.lead_paragraph: As governor of Wisconsin, Tommy G. Thompson complained mightily about a federal bureaucracy that was too controlling, too inflexible, too slow. As secretary of health and human services, he is now in the belly of the beast. This week, in fact, he temporarily moved his office to Baltimore, to the headquarters of the bureaucracy that Republicans most love to hate -- the Health Care Financing Administration, the department's unit that administers Medicare and Medicaid.

headline.main: Serving Along the Front Line In Battle for the Bush Agenda

docs.abstract: Article on Republicans who are taking on task of actually carrying out Pres Bush's 'compassionate conservatism'; former Gov Tommy Thompson, who complained mightily about federal bureaucracy, now finds himself in belly of beast as health and human services secretary, with budget bigger than that of all but five countries; other Republicans in period of adjustment include returning veterans Mitchell E Daniels Jr at OMB and Margaret La Montagne, domestic policy assistant working on education; interviews; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a decision that makes it easier for Medicare patients to sue their health maintenance organizations, the California Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the widow of an Orange County businessman was entitled to seek compensation under state tort laws. Critics of H.M.O.'s said the 5-to-2 ruling was part of a trend by courts to scale back the immunity from lawsuits that has protected managed care companies.

headline.main: California Court Upholds Patient's Right to Sue an H.M.O.

docs.abstract: California Supreme Court, in 5-2 decision that makes it easier for Medicare patients to sue their health maintenance organizations, rules that Barbara McCall, widow of George McCall, is entitled to seek compensation under state tort laws; critics of HMO's say ruling is part of trend by courts to scale back immunity from lawsuits that has protected managed care companies; Jon N Manzanares, lawyer for defendant, PacifiCare Health Systems, says decision is 'ripe for review' by US Supreme Court (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The budget compromise worked out this week by Republican negotiators and the White House became snagged in technicalities today, and a final Congressional vote was postponed until next week. Leaders in the House and Senate said the complications had nothing to do with the basic measure, which would allow $1.35 trillion in tax cuts over the next 11 years and nearly $2 trillion in federal spending next year. The leaders said they were sure the measure would be passed.

headline.main: Haggling Over Technicalities Delays Voting on Budget

docs.abstract: Budget compromise worked out by Republican negotiators and White House is snagged in technicalities, and final Congressional vote is postponed for a week; one technical difficulty has to do with jurisdictional dispute in House over which committee would be in charge of $5 billion in emergency spending and how this money would be accounted for in budget; photo (M)

byline.original: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Electronic Data Systems, the big Texas-based computer service company, said it had won $1 billion in contracts from four organizations around the world. The company signed a 10-year, $390 million contract from the British lender Abbey National; three contracts with BellSouth; a two-year contract with the Board of the Austrian Insurance Agencies; and a five-year deal with Afrox, a South African gas and health care concern. Last week, E.D.S. reported first-quarter earnings that met Wall Street's expectations, announced that it expected to do so for the rest of the year and said that it had its ninth consecutive quarter of record signings. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline.main: Technology Briefing | Hardware: E.D.S. Gets Service Contracts

docs.abstract: Electronic Data Systems, computer service company, wins $1 billion in contracts from Abbey National, BellSouth, Board of Austrian Insurance Agencies and South Africa's Afrox (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Democrats Warn Bush Not to Scrap ABM Treaty Some of the most influential Senate Democratic voices on national security policy said they would consider it a grave mistake for President Bush to abrogate the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, and they made clear that his plans for a missile defense system could become a point of contention between the two parties. A1 Although the shield Mr. Bush wants to build is based on unproven weapons systems, military officials and experts say his proposals seem more likely than earlier ones to result in deployment of some kind of system. A10

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation, one of the strongest managed care companies, said yesterday that profits would be lower than expected this year, blaming weaker earnings from pension and retirement accounts that it manages for large employers. Analysts, however, were particularly concerned by an unexpected increase in Cigna's medical costs. Cigna's announcement touched off a selling wave that drove down Cigna shares and other H.M.O. stocks. And it followed a warning three weeks ago by Aetna Inc., the largest health insurer, which said on April 10 that its first-quarter earnings would be lower than expected because of sharply rising medical costs. Analysts had discounted the Aetna warning somewhat, believing it was a special case tied to Aetna's problems with overly rapid expansion and friction with doctors.

headline.main: Cigna Warns on Profits, and H.M.O. Stocks Take a Tumble

docs.lead_paragraph: A billboard erected yesterday in Times Square by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association provoked another clash over long-stalled city contract negotiations, with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani saying that the union had skewed its comparisons of police wages. The 680-square-foot billboard, hung from a second-story facade on Broadway between 46th Street and 47th Street, was unveiled by union officials yesterday morning.

headline.main: Mayor Says Union Billboard Misstates Police Compensation

docs.abstract: Billboard erected in Times Square by Patrolmen's Benevolent Association provokes another clash over long-stalled city contract negotiations, with Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani saying that union comparisons of police wages are not accurate; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The State House of Representatives unanimously passed a bill that took a first step toward a statewide health insurance plan for teachers. The bill, sponsored by Representative Paul Sadler, chairman of the House Public Education Committee, would provide state money to create a mandatory insurance pool for rural and poor school districts, some of which have not been able to afford health coverage for their employees. The statewide plan for teacher health insurance has been among the most contentious issues of the legislative session because of the potentially large pricetag. The Senate must now consider the bill. Jim Yardley (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing/SOUTHWEST: TEXAS: HEALTH COVERAGE FOR TEACHERS

docs.lead_paragraph: New York residents have begun receiving notices that they may prevent their insurance companies from sharing their personal financial information and health records with other companies. In Connecticut, a similar notice covers the sharing of financial records. The notices, along with directions for policyholders to exercise their choices, flow from a 1999 federal law that requires all the states to put measures into effect this year to regulate insurers' sharing of customers' personal information if they do not already have such regulations.

headline.main: Consumers to Get a Choice on Insurers' Sharing of Data
